frameDefinitions: This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
A Cognizer has a relatively fixed positive or negative point of view towards an Issue.
This frame is concerned with Cognizers remembering and forgetting mental Content.
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
This frame has to do with the bias or lack of bias of a Judge making an assessment concerning two or more Sides.
This frame contains nouns denoting Aggregates of Individuals.
frameExamples: Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
In interviews , it seems like everyone is completely <t>against</t> this expenditure .
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
An <t><fex name='Agg'>army</fex></t> of postal workers descended on my office.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The individual that holds an opinion on an <fen>Issue</fen> or Side.
The matter, usually concerning a course of action, which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a positive or negative opinion about.
The party or individual (generally associated with a particular position on an <fen>Issue</fen>) that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has an opinion about.
An action taken by a <fen>Side</fen> or a view that the <fen>Side</fen> takes on an issue which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> either supports or opposes.
The time period during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has the indicated point of view towards the <fen>Issue</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> takes <fen>Side</fen>s on an <fen>Issue</fen> .
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose mental <fen>Content</fen> is at issue.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the mental content that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> retains or forgets.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject the <fen>Cognizer</fen> mental <fen>Content</fen> is about.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the remembering or forgetting of mental <fen>Content</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the remembering or forgetting takes place.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
This Frame Element marks the person whose objectivity in making assesment is being evaluated.
This Frame Element marks one of the <fen>Sides</fen> in a dispute or one of the alternatives in a situation of choice.
This Frame Element marks phrases jointly expressing both <fen>Sides</fen> in a dispute or all of the alternatives in a situation of choice.
The second-mentioned of the <fen>Sides</fen> to a dispute or alternatives in a situation of choice.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate how the bias of the <fen>Judge</fen> expresses itself in their behavior or actions.
The <fen>Dispute</fen> is the situation in which there is some conflict between two sides.
The individual whose point of view is taken in assigning the judgment denoted by the target.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part which indicates the character of the <fen>Decision_maker</fen>.
This role denotes the time when the partiality occurs.
This role identifies the people or things that form  the <fen>Aggregate</fen>.
This role identifies the collection of entities that are the <fen>Aggregate</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> she opposed the bill, but changed her mind after she received correspondence supporting the bill.
Each student must be able to recall <fex>the whole paragraph</fex>  .
<fex>The referee</fex> was totally biased against our team.
The umpire was partial <fex>to the home team</fex>.
The judge was neutral <fex>between the parties</fex>.
The judge favored the defendant <fex>over the plaintiff</fex>.
My sister remained neutral <fex>in our disputes</fex>.
He had a neutral <fex>smile</fex> on his face.
A crowd <fex>of hoodlums</fex> filled the plaza.
A <fex><t>crowd</t></fex> of hoodlums filled the plaza.
